prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the WIBTA question is in the wrong. The situation is that the author's girlfriend has been staying with him after a fight with her parents, and things were okay until her friend started coming over. The author is upset because when the friend is there, the girlfriend acts differently—being catty, making him feel laughed at, and even dismissing his presence. The author wants to tell the girlfriend to stop bringing her friend over.

First, I need to assess if the author is in the wrong. The key points here are communication, boundaries, and mutual respect in the relationship. The author clearly communicated that the stay was temporary, so maybe the girlfriend staying longer than expected is an issue. However, the main problem is the friend's presence and how it affects their dynamic.

The author mentions specific incidents where he felt disrespected by the friend and his girlfriend. The friend's comment about the man having an opinion being a "shocker" is particularly hurtful. The girlfriend's change in behavior around her friend is significant. The author wants to set a boundary by not allowing the friend to come over anymore, which seems reasonable if the friend's presence is causing a toxic environment.

But are there any aspects where the author might be at fault? Maybe he didn't address the issue sooner, allowing the situation to escalate. Perhaps he should have discussed his discomfort with the girlfriend earlier instead of letting it build up. However, the girlfriend is changing her behavior when her friend is present, which points more towards the friend's influence rather than the author's actions.

The author wants to push the girlfriend to reconcile with her parents, which might be a good idea if the stay was supposed to be temporary, but that's separate from the friend issue. The main question is about the friend's presence. The author's intention is to stop further conflict and restore peace in their living space, which is a valid reason. 

On the other hand, if the author hasn't communicated his feelings to the girlfriend about how the friend's presence affects him, maybe he should have done that first. But since he is now considering setting a boundary, it's a proactive step. The friend's behavior seems to be the root of the problem, not the author. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong for wanting to set this boundary. So the answer would be B (No).
